data.title: Custom theme values: Certain color conventions do not work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.5

Regarding test item #11126
1. Try entering a shorthand hex color value in any field.  An example would be `#fff` for white or `#000` for black—instead of `#ffffff` or `#000000` respectively.
2. Now try entering named colors, like `black` or `white`

Neither of these situations work.  Perhaps number 2 is by design (but I think we at a minimum should support number 1).

data.title: Add initialValue? to QuickPickOptions
data.body:
It's sometimes necessary to get a pre-filled QuickPick. In my usecase, I want to
write an extension to navigate directories, and to do this, I need the QuickPick
to be pre-filled with the current directory.

I couldn't test this, because I couldn't figure out for the life of me how to load up an extension in the dev vscode. I know about `~/.vscode-oss-dev`, but I keep running into problems with the `vscode.ts.d` (I had to hand-edit this) and `engines.vscode` settings. Surely, there's a less painful way to co-develop vscode and extensions!

data.title: Custom theme values: Current-line has ghost border that makes a color not take full line-height
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.5

Regarding test item #11126

![screen shot 2016-08-30 at 5 29 44 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11839736/18114043/e1bfd058-6ee8-11e6-97b5-000fc8ed2a31.png)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set the `lineHighlight` value in a tmTheme
2. Note that the color you choose does not appear to take up the whole height of the line.  This is because there is a `border: 2px solid` on it which is squeezing the decoration's background to be smaller.

Removing this border whenever someone using a non-default line-highlight style should fix it.

Thanks.

data.title: Update documentation for vscode.previewHtml
data.body: The [documentation](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/api/node/extHostApiCommands.ts#L167) for `vscode.previewHtml` should describe that vscode annotates the body of the html page with one of the following css classes `vscode-light`, `vscode-dark`, or `vscode-high-contrast` in order to communicate to the contents what kind of theme is currently used by vscode.

data.title: Feature request: Allow empty editor e.g. don't close editor when last tab/file is closed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open a file
2. Open 2 more editors to get three-panel view by hitting "cmd+\"
3. Close file in right editor

Expected: File in right editor closes but editor/panel stays expanded, retaining desired three-panel view.
Result: File closes but so does editor, so that only 2 editors in 2-panel view are left.
## Request:

Allow empty editors/panels. If all tabs are closed for an editor it should stay open. (An option for this would be great i.e. `workspace.allowEmptyEditors`, `workspace.dontCloseEmptyEditor` or whatever.)
## Context/User-Perspective:

**tl;dr**: Just because I closed the last tab for an editor doesn't mean I want the layout to change. I just don't want that file open anymore.

My reasoning for this preference is that I like to keep my workspace "clean" as it were. I like to focus on the code I'm currently working on and only really keep other files open as reference material. Visually speaking, I also like having the file I'm currently working on centered. Currently I have to keep adjusting the editor's widths depending on how many are open and which files I've closed. It'd be nice to just have a fixed 3 panel layout like what is possible in SublimeText.
## Examples

The behavior I'm looking for can be seen in SublimeText:

Notice here the right tab-group has no files but is still there.
![screen shot 2016-08-30 at 6 53 27 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1890516/18111210/59576c30-6ee3-11e6-857c-385d57a36973.png)

And in this one I've closed all the files in the left tab group but it stays open. In VS Code this would cause the left editor to collapse and the middle editor to be the first.
![screen shot 2016-08-30 at 6 53 35 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1890516/18111209/59565af2-6ee3-11e6-99ee-fa04903f4757.png)

data.title: CPP extension crashes a lot (once a day or so)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6
- OS Version: El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
Okay, it's very hard to come up with reproduction steps. I'm describing the pattern. I work on a huge codebase, and ignore 90% of everything using `ignore` so that <kbd>Cmd+P</kbd> can work. I usually have a lot of tabs open (15+). Once a day or two, vscode becomes unresponsive, a stray vscode process has taken up 100% of cpu. If I keep using vscode, it eventually grinds to a halt and crashes.

Fixing this issue should be top priority.

data.title: No IntelliSense for single file.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders
- OS Version: Mac 

Related #11258

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new file `person.js`
2. Add this code. 

``` js
function Person(name, age) {
    this.name = name;
    this.age = age;
}

var p = new Person()
```

I expect to see IntelliSense or even word completion, but I am not. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/18110756/dfdc4b8c-6ece-11e6-95ec-6f7c0f9334cd.png)

I see this when logging tsserver output. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/18110761/e9488c44-6ece-11e6-8c4c-42cc51832bb0.png)

Others in the office cannot reproduce this. I can reproduce it on my machine multiple times. I have also observed this starting to work after a time and also IntelliSense will stop working after a time. 

It seemed like the problem was with TypeScript Language Service. I tried the following:
1. Restarted VS Code - still not resolved
2. Killing tsserver.js process - still not resolved, although I did confirm the process restarted. 
3. I updated TypeScript to RC with `npm install -g typescript@rc`. Did not solve the issue. 
4. I looked in `Console.app` on the mac to see any errors logged. 

What other ways can I try and debug this? 
Is there a way to see the error logs for Electron? 
Do we think this is a TypeScript Language Service issue?

data.title: Debug Vscode by Nodejs and Express
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.1

Hi,

I am trying to debug  my code inside Visual studio code by launching nodejs.
The procedures are as below:

1- In a specific folder (/home/s/workspace/ myui) I have created  files(server.js,package.json) for node settings:
Note: The path is outside of my project
a)First file is :
server.js:

```
var express = require('express');
var app = express();
app.use(
    express.static("/home/s/git/ui") //where your static content is located in your filesystem
);
app.listen(3002, function () {
  console.log('Express server listening on port 3001!');
});

```

b)second file in that path is:
package.json:

```
{
  "name": "myui",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "server.js",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "concurrently \"npm run tsc:w\" \"npm run server\" ",
    "server": "node server.js",
    "tsc": "tsc",
    "tsc:w": "tsc -w -p /home/s/git/ui"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
   "dependencies": {
    "concurrently": "^2.2.0",
    "express": "^4.14.0"
  }
}
```

Next, I have a project in different path:(/home/s/git/ui)

![projectpath](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/20918866/18110457/5d2e434c-6f5b-11e6-8eb0-1d1e4b236b0d.png)

and in each folder, there are js and ts files.and there is no a seprated folder for putting all typescript files. all of them are besides their js.

last step is my launch.json:

```
{
 "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "DEBUG",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/myui/server.js",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [],
             "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "preLaunchTask": "",
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/app",

            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env":{
                "NODE_ENV":"development"
            },
            "port": 5858,
            "externalConsole": false

        },
        {
            "name": "Attach to url with files served from ./out",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
               "stopOnEntry": true,


             "outDir":null,
           "sourceMaps": true,
             "address": "localhost",
       // "preLaunchTask": "",
           "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "restart": false,
             "remoteRoot": null,
            "port": 3002

        }
    ]
}
```

But when I choose launch for debugging, it just `shows following log in my console and breakpoints are not triggered.

node --debug-brk=5858 --nolazy myui/server.js 
Debugger listening on port 5858
Express server listening on port 3002!

and when I try to attach the project to the specific url, nothing happen.

What is wrong in my settings?

Thanks in advance

data.title: Removing several commands from commandsToSkipShell has no effect
data.body:
Testing #11137
- VSCode Version:1.5.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add default terminal.integrated.commandsToSkipShell
2. Remove workbench.action.terminal.copySelection, Ctrl+Shift+C still copies selected text
3. Remove workbench.action.terminal.toggleTerminal, Ctrl+` still toggles terminal panel
4. Remove workbench.action.terminal.kill, Ctrl+Shift+` still creates new terminal

Perhaps I don't understand how this is supposed to work.

data.title: Inefficient Toggle with Integrated Terminal when Running IPython

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.40
- OS Version: Windows 10 v. 1511
- IPython Version: 5.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open integrated terminal and run `ipython`.
2. In editor (do not hide terminal window), type `print('hello world')`.
3. Highlight text and use VS Code command `Terminal: Run Selected Text in Active Terminal`.

At this stage, the code has loaded into the iPython terminal but has not actually executed.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/21263827/18107572/123a3f36-6ece-11e6-8118-236f8793a3a9.PNG)

The user is required to press Enter in the terminal pane to actually execute the code. (Visual Studio Community with PTVS works as expected: the script runs upon Shift+Alt+F5.) You will notice in the screenshot that after running the selected text, the curor is still in the code panel. Therefore, if you press Enter (in an attempt to execute the code in the terminal pane), your selected text in the editor will be deleted. The only way to complete the code run in the terminal is to, after step 3, either (a) mouse over and click in the terminal panel and hit Enter, or (b) hit Ctrl+` twice to hide and show the terminal panel (which will also focus the panel) and then hit Enter. This is inefficient. The code should either fully execute upon the run command (as it does in Visual Studio) or the terminal pane should automatically focus so the user can hit enter to complete the code run.

Note that when the terminal window is hidden at the time the selected code is run, the terminal opens and is simultaneously focused. The user can then hit Enter to complete the run with little additional effort.

data.title: Bad Font Rendering on Light themes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4; 
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607, build 14393.51
- Resolution: 1440 x 900, 18.5 Inches Dell Monitor

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open Visual Studio Code, switch theme to Light+ 
2.  Switch theme to Monokai
3. The font rendering quality is way better on dark theme.

Proof:

Light Theme: http://imgur.com/a/u1YA6
Dark Theme: http://imgur.com/a/XDlKe

The truth is: Windows Font Rendering on any monitor with less than 200 ppi will have poor quality. Visual Studio Code should use another font rendering engine

data.title: Support overriding mode in editor
Is it possible to call a command registered in an extension from the tasks.json?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I have a VS Code extension which registered a command via vscode.commands.registerCommand('extension.sayHello').

Is there anyway I can define a task in tasks.json which invokes this command?

```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "vscode", // here
    "isShellCommand": false,
    "args": [],
        "tasks": [
            {
                "taskName": "sayHello", // here
                "suppressTaskName": true,
                "args": [],
                "isBuildCommand": false,
                "showOutput": "always",
                "echoCommand": true
            }
        ]
}
```

Alternatively, is it possible to invoke this command from preLaunchTask in launch.json?

```
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name":"Test",
            "request": "launch",
            "preLaunchTask": "vscode.extension.sayHello" // here?
        }
    ]
```

data.title: Integrated Terminal: After clearing screen, scroll up shows previous output
data.body:
Testing #11134
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open an integrated terminal and execute a command that gives an output. Example: `dir`
2. Now clear the screen using `cls`

Expected: The screen clears up and you can't scroll up anymore
Actual:     The screen does clear up. But you can scroll up to find the previous output

In an external terminal, there is no scrolling up after `cls`

data.title: Syntax highlighting in C++ mode broken by macro
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
Paste this in, and watch the syntax highlighter break:

``` c++
#undef _R_
#define ASSERT_OR_NOTE                                                  \
    _R_(opts & NOTEODDITY, opts & NEGATIVE, NOTE_ODDITY, doesNotContainTokens) \
    _R_(opts & NOTEODDITY, !(opts & NEGATIVE), NOTE_ODDITY, containsTokens) \
    _R_(!(opts & NOTEODDITY), opts & NEGATIVE, ASSERT_THAT, doesNotContainTokens) \
    _R_(!(opts & NOTEODDITY), !(opts & NEGATIVE), ASSERT_THAT, containsTokens)
```

data.title: showTextDocument should support to open in the background
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a document with `openTextDocument`
2. Then show the resulting document with the preserveFocus argument set to true `showTextDocument(TextDocument, vscode.ViewColumn.One, true)`
3. A new editor opens and still gains focus
